title: Georgia's Congressional Race to Replace Marjorie Taylor Greene
summary: A crowded field of 22 candidates is vying to succeed Marjorie Taylor Greene in Georgia's 14th Congressional District after her resignation. The candidates include 17 Republicans, 3 Democrats, a Libertarian, and an independent, reflecting diverse political interests. The election will use an all-party ballot on March 10, with a runoff scheduled for April 7 if no candidate secures a majority. The district, rated as the most Republican-leaning in Georgia by the Cook Political Report, historically supported Greene's hard-right positions. Key Republican contenders are Clay Fuller, a former district attorney from Trenton who placed fourth in the 2020 primary won by Greene, and Colton Moore, a state senator known for his right-wing alignment with the Freedom Caucus. Nicky Lama, a Dalton City Council member elected in 2023, promises next-generation conservatism. This special election follows Greene's tumultuous five-year tenure and highlights the district's strong Republican base, with candidates aiming to appeal to voters in an area stretching from Atlanta's northwest suburbs to the Tennessee border.

background_read: In U.S. politics, congressional seats represent districts in the House of Representatives, with members elected to two-year terms. Special elections occur when a seat becomes vacant due to resignation, death, or other reasons, as with Marjorie Taylor Greene's departure. Georgia's 14th Congressional District is known for its strong Republican lean, influenced by suburban and rural voters. The Cook Political Report provides nonpartisan analysis of such districts, helping understand electoral dynamics. Candidates like Clay Fuller and Colton Moore highlight the role of local political experience, such as serving as district attorney or state legislator, in congressional races. The all-party ballot system used here means voters choose from all candidates regardless of party, potentially leading to runoffs if no majority is achieved. This election reflects broader trends in American politics, where hard-right conservatism and party competition shape outcomes in key regions.
